Key Point

If the auxiliary equation has two equal roots, \(k\), the complementary function is: \[y_\text{cf}=(A+Bx)\text{e}^{kx}\]

Example

The auxiliary equation of \(ay''+by'+cy=0\) is \(ak^2+bk+c=0.\) Suppose this equation has equal roots \(k=k_1\) and \(k=k_1\). Verify that \(y=x\text{e}^{k_1x}\) is a solution of the differential equation.

Solution

We have: \[ y=x\text{e}^{k_1x}\qquad\quad y'=\text{e}^{k_1x}(1+k_1x)\qquad\quad y''=\text{e}^{k_1x}(k_1^2x+2k_1)\] Substitution into the left-hand side of the differential equation yields: \[ \text{e}^{k_1x}\{a(k^2_1x+2k_1)+b(1+k_1x)+cx\}=\text{e}^{k_1x}\{(ak_1^2+bk_1+c)x+2ak_1+b\}\] But \(ak_1^2+bk_1+c=0\) since \(k_1\) satisfies the auxiliary equation. Also, \[ k_1={-b\pm\sqrt{b^2-4ac}\over 2a}\] but since the roots are equal, then \(b^2-4ac=0\) hence \(k_1=-b/2a\). So \(2ak_1+b=0\). Hence \[\text{e}^{k_1x}\{(ak_1^2+bk_1+c)x+2ak_1+b\}=\text{e}^{k_1x}\{(0)x+0\}=0\] We conclude that \(y=x\text{e}^{k_1x}\) is a solution of \(ay''+by'+cy=0\) when the roots of the auxiliary equation are equal. This illustrates the previous Key Point.

Example

Obtain the general solution of the equation: \[ {d^2y\over dx^2}+8{dy\over dx}+16y=0.\]

Solution

As before, a trial solution of the form \(y=\text{e}^{kx}\) yields an auxiliary equation \(k^2+8k+16=0\). This equation factorizes so that \((k+4)(k+4)=0\) and we obtain equal roots, that is, \(k=-4\) (twice). If we proceed as before, writing \(y_1(x)=\text{e}^{-4x}\) \(y_2(x)=\text{e}^{-4x},\) it is clear that the two solutions are not independent. We need to find a second independent solution. Using the result summarised in the previous Key Point, we conclude that the second independent solution is \(y_2=x\text{e}^{-4x}\). The general solution is then: \[ y(x)=(A+Bx)\text{e}^{-4x}\]
